physDesc.p: This letter is 9 pages long (seq. 100-108). It is typed on good quality typing paper (neither notebook paper nor Lowell’s nice cardstock, but somewhere in between). The words “John Gould Fletcher” are written in pencil across the top of the first page.

text.body:
March 29, 1917 Dear J.G.F.:
I was delighted to get your letter of March 6th yesterday morning, for, to tell the truth, I was somewhat upset by the one of February 12th, which came a couple of weeks ago; upset because I did not quite agree with your point of view in it, and I hate to disagree with you always, and particularly when you are so far away, but this new letter, in which you have changed your mind, agrees with me exactly.
You see the point is this: – As you say, possibly Miss Weaver would not sell her paper, particularly as you planned to leave her as editor. In that case she would go around and tell everybody that she had been approached – she might even call it “bribed” – to run her paper a certain way, and she could make a very nasty story about that. Also, suppose she did consent to leave Ezra out of the paper for a consideration, it would give Ezra a splendid handle to beat us with, because he would know perfectly well where the money came from, and he would not only be able to enlist the sympathy of the outside world and pose as a martyr to capital, and I think he might be able to hurt us very seriously by leaving the impression with the public at large that our success was largely due to methods of this kind. I do not believe that any good is to be gained by trying to muzzle one's enemies. That is the action of weakness, and is sure to come back on the perpetrator like a boomerang. The only thing for us to do is to write more and better until Ezra is acknowledged by the world at large to be out of the running with us. I think it only needs time for that to be a fact; besides, Ezra is so curiously constituted that if you only give him rope enough, he will hang himself. If he is permitted to say pretty much what he wants in
“The Egoist”, he will soon disgust people so thoroughly that he will have no chance at all. The only reason he has any influence still is because his remarks are so carefully edited before they are allowed to appear. Harriet Monroe told me, when I was in Chicago, that she had to blue pencil all his articles so as to make them possible at all, which does not mean that Harriet is getting tired of him, because I think she is peculiarly loyal, as far as he is concerned. This was just a statement of fact.
Personally, I hate “The Egoist”, and if it were not a seeming disloyalty to the others of the group, I would discontinue my subscription at once. The thing has practically no circulation; even in England it is almost unknown, outside of a small group, and to be in it or out of it makes not the slightest difference in any way. I have not observed that writing in it has helped any one to a wider public, nor has it gained for any of its contributors the entrance to any other magazine; therefore, I would not worry about it at all or let Ezra’s being in it or out of it give you a moment’s discomfort.
I am awfully sorry you are so blue. I do not wonder at it at all, and I assure you that your being away this winter has added very materially to the difficulties of writing for me. I got so much inspiration out of our Sunday talks, and talking to you did so much to clear my ideas and to show me what I really thought; also, I think the contact of our two minds whetted us both to make discoveries, which we should not have made alone, (at least that was the case with me) and I have missed you terribly. Mrs. Russell and I have often said what would we not
give to see you again. I think you are quite right, however, not to make the voyage or subject your wife to it with this submarine menace going on. Think how foolish you would feel as you sank beneath the waves to realize that you had cut your life short, and deprived the world of what you will write in the future, for a mere caprice!
Now that we are certainly going to enter the war, I think a great strain is off the people in this part of the country. We have always been pro Ally, and to be able to be so with all our might and main is a relief. I think there is going to be some difficulty between the English elements and the German elements in our population, and I suspect that many friendships of long duration will be snapped, but, on the whole, I believe that this will have the effect of making America more homogenous, more truly a nation, than it has been for many years – since this vast tide of immigration has done so much to change the temper of her people, in fact.
I enclose a poem which I wrote a few weeks ago and put in the “Transcript”, as it seemed to me a daily paper was the place for it. It has been very well liked. Many people, including Ellery Sedgwick (which is a joke), think it is one of the best things I have done. Anyhow, it came from my heart. I rather wish it could be printed in an English daily paper, but I have no way of knowing how that could be done. Perhaps the “Observer” would print it. If you feel like taking it round to them, I should be very glad. Of course the fact that it appeared in the Boston “Transcript” should be mentioned.
I was perfectly wild over your poems for the new Anthology.
I think “Moonlight” and “Dawn” are two of the most beautiful things you have done, and they fill me with envy, malice, and all uncharitableness. I do not believe you need worry about whether or not you have retrograded or advanced as a poet. There are always “ups and downs” periods in every poet’s creative life, and being so near the active seat of war makes it very difficult to write, naturally. It will be after the war is over, as a recollected experience, that you will find what you have gained.
As to our fellow Imagists, I quite agree with you that Aldington is far and away the best of the lot. I have full belief in him, as a poet possibly more than as an essay writer, and as to his character, it is “sans peur et sans reproche”. Flint has always been an exceedingly conceited fellow. The amount of swelled head he has managed to acquire, with very little reason therefor, is unique in my experience. Hilda is faded – so faded physically, that I think it affects her mentally. I do not wonder that Miss Weaver got discouraged with her; as an editor she must be absolutely useless. In regard to Lawrence, he has always been primarily a novelist, and only a poet as a side show. As such, he need not seriously concern us.
Still, I do not know whether we are wise to discontinue the Imagist Anthology, just at this point, or not. England seems to be waking up to us. The English are a queer people. If you hammer, hammer, hammer, bye and bye they will pay attention. It always takes years before they realize that anything has anything in it. Now they have just begun to see that we amount to something, and whether or not it
is wise to discontinue our collective publication at the very moment that it is beginning to be noticed over there, I cannot quite make up my mind. Of course the production of the individual poets has something to do with it. I do not know what Richard will be able to produce in the trenches. The other three seem to be hopeless, but there are always you and I. Anyway, I am going to talk the matter over with Feris Greenslet when he comes back. We do not want to lose any of the ground we have gained either by inadequate production or by ceasing any publication just as soon as it is beginning to be noticed.
As far as America is concerned, I do not think there is any advantage in keeping on the Anthology. It has done its business with the American public. The word “Imagist” and the kind of poetry for which we stand is now thoroughly recognized, and I think we can do quite as well on our own hooks, as we can together, but the situation is so different in England that I do not feel in a position to form an opinion at present. At any rate, I shall form none without first consulting you, after I have seen Ferris Greenslet. He has not come home, and Mr. Scaife does not know when he will come. Nobody knows whether he is on the water, or where he is, as announcements of sailings have been discontinued in the papers, and he would not be allowed to cable his own departure. There is, therefore, nothing to be done at present but to wait until his arrival.
Our book will be out about the middle of April. Of course I shall send you a copy as soon as it comes. I sent you a copy of Harriet’s Anthology, which is just out a week or so ago. Of course it is not exactly
the selection I would have made myself in all instances. I would never have left out your “Green Symphony”, for instance, which I think is, on the whole, finer than the “Blue”; still, I must admit that I think it is a very creditable volume and shows that the poetical renaissance, which we claim to exist, is a fact and not a fancy.
You will be amused to hear that Braithwaite has had a fight with Edgett and has left the “Transcript”. The reviews of his Anthology have been uniformly bad, and I am afraid his unbusinesslike methods have made them mad in there, but they did not kick him out; he kicked himself out in a fit of spleen, thinking himself more valuable than he really is. You will probably be glad to know of this, but I am sincerely sorry, for I believe the alternative will be Nathan Haskell Dole, which will be most unfortunate. They are neither of them bright, but Dole is a malicious dolt, whereas Braithwaite is merely ignorant, and he certainly is kindly.
“The Transcript” had a review of Harriet’s Anthology by Kate Buss, which I will send you, and you will see how inadequately this sort of work will be done on the “Transcript”, if Braithwaite doesn’t do it. Also, this little notice was on the back page, not on the book page at all. Now this is one of the most important books that has come out lately, and to treat it this way shows a narrow-mindedness which is a disgrace to a paper like the “Transcript”. At least Braithwaite insisted upon space.
I am sorry that you felt obliged to jump on him so hard in the “Poetry Review”, because I think it is just this sort of thing which has forced him out, and in all these considerations, it is a question of what is going to be the result of any action. If jumping out of the frying
pan means jumping into the fire, you had better stay in the frying pan. Anyway, I send you two clippings from the “Transcript”, which speak for themselves, but which will show you that Edgett read your review. I am inclined to think that this, and the many hostile reviews which his new Anthology has received, is responsible for their attitude towards him. I have no brief to hold for his work, as you know, but I think Edgett and Dole, as a combination, would be very much worse. Also, I am sorry for Braithwaite, and it looks to me now as though he would starve. Ignorance I can forgive; malicious underhandedness, I cannot.
My trip out West was eminently successful, as far as it went. I spoke in the Medical School in St. Louis, under the auspices of the Washington University Alumni Association, and the hall was so crowded that they had to put in seventy-five extra chairs. The enthusiasm was tremendous. I met Orrick Johns while I was there, and he assumed disposed to be friendly and enthusiastic to all of us and did not at all take the tone which Williams took in the Autumn.
Kreymborg is reading his poems to the sound of a “mandalute” – whatever that may be – but I do not think that sort of freak stuff is likely to work very long. Kreymborg is a clever fellow, and if he did not have some admixture of the charlatan in his composition, I think he would be an interesting fellow. But the older I get, the more I value sincerity, and the less I care twopence for any one who has not got it. I have his advertisement somewhere; if I can find it, I will send it to you.
I also send you a copy of a review of Braithwaite’s Anthology
by Aiken in “The Dial”. I think this is much better than his critical work usually is. It is more restrained and less bumptious; in fact, I quite like this review.
You will be amused to learn that Maurice Browne failed the day before I arrived in Chicago, so I only gave my lecture for Harriet, and gave up the others, as I did not want to run the risk myself, and there had been no time to advertise them properly.
I think that Harriet has run her poetry talks into the ground. Having one every Sunday by so many poets, most of whom cannot read aloud at all, I think it had rather weakened people’s interest, although my hall was so crowded that they slopped over into the adjoining room. I believe that conditions here are getting more normal. I think that the “boom” is decidedly over. Vachel Lindsay tells me that nobody wants him any more, and it seems to me that as people are getting more educated, they are beginning to distinguish between the really serious artists and those with the scholarly intent, and the half-baked ones. Also the close proximity of war is taking people’s attention off the freaks. The result may be a less apparent demand for the works of the modern poets, but I believe the real ones stand more chance of being appreciated than they ever have before. In other words, the conditions, I hope, will settle down more to that of England than it has been for some time.
You will be glad to hear that “Sword Blades” has gone into a third edition, so that I think we are moving.
William Aspinwall Bradley is here, and spoke so pleasantly of
you the other night. He said he enjoyed that evening you passed together very much, and he wishes you were here, and I echoed him with all my heart.
You will be amused to hear that they have kicked me out of the Presidency of the Poetry Club, and Josephine has practically come out as my avowed enemy. She still tries to hide it under a cloak of friendship, but I am on guard. I shall not go to the Poetry Society again, and I am thankful that I am out of it. It is getting perfectly impossible, and they are asking the Harvard boys for every meeting. Bradley, who went last time, told me that those old women kow-towed to the young men in a perfectly ridiculous way which made him quite sick. He says he shall not go again, either.
I am off to Buffalo tonight for a lecture tomorrow, or rather a reading, and I am to go to Bryn Mawr in May. Also, I hope to see Mr. Patterson when I am passing through New York in May. I have had several letters from him, but very little can be done that way.
This is a terribly long letter, and does my best to make up for the good talk I wish we could have. I do wish you would come back and settle in Boston for good, but I suppose that would be too good to be true.
Please remember me most kindly to your wife, if you can be remembered to a person whom you have never seen, and believe me
Affectionately yours,,
